Discipline_isced: Mathematics and Statistics;Computing;Architecture and Urban Planning
Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: Incredibly useful - necessary, even.
It's fun!

I do not collaborate very much within my own discipline (my laboratory publishes independently without co-authors from other laboratories in the same field), but I do collaborate moderately frequently with researchers in other disciplines.
5 stars, would recommend
HIghly necessary

I think the summer school does an excellent job of bringing together people from diverse fields to learn, and importantly learn from each other. I think this experience was easier for me than others because all of us had at least the same level of knowledge about the topics taught on the summer school. I think bring researchers together for these kinds of short intensive experiences also really helps, because you exist in a microcosm of complexity research and the ideas flow all the time, including during work breaks, during class and (most importantly) during nights out drinking margaritas.
Excellent. One my most cited papers came from a collaboration with a Biologist.

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Mathematics and Statistics;Engineering
Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: Useful from an academic perspective, less useful from a professional perspective
[the project is not published but is on its second round of reviews, so I did answer the "how difficult was it to publish" question]
Very important and useful.  Best for mid-career people.  Early career people are still sorting themselves out.

Awesome, of course. But I take it that it varies from person to person. I take the view of the "cross pollinator" (a metaphor I first heard in Santa Fe), we need "single-field specialists", and I'm glad they exist, but I think we need a certain amount of cross pollination between fields, done by the people who have the vocation for the kind of interdisciplinary work that characterizes the Santa Fe Institute and the CSSS.
Essential to the advancement of science
A must

Just having interdisciplinary conversations can be very fruitful. They can help spark ideas and inspire one to take different directions. However, if your goal is to work together, they do take a lot of work in making sure everyone speaks the same "language" and understand the other disciplines at least in a cursory manner. Everyone involved must be ready to put in the time and energy into sustaining the effort.
Great way to go forward in Science! Even if it doesn't immediately yield 'results' in terms of papers/publications it does give a more broad perspective on your own research field.
A+
Very enlighting
I enjoyed the friendships and cross-pollination of ideas.

I think interdisciplinary work is invaluable. However, I find myself more open to cross-disciplinary collaboration than I find people in other disciplines to be. I think that people who are willing to venture outside of their own realms to bring their expertise to bear on other disciplines are relatively rare. Nevertheless, I have persisted with work that is in the approximate area of complexity and am finding more people interested in applying this work to my field of medicine as time goes by.

CSSS is an amazing place and experience. Depending on your field and focus, the time spent there can be transformative and yield fruitful collaborations. While my own career path moved in a different direction, I anticipate that my experience at CSSS will continue to color the way that I approach scientific endeavors in perpetuity.
It should be implicit in everything we do!
Difficult to get credited for it by traditional systems of evaluation.
Best way to make a meaningful contribution.

Very important, but very hard. The current academic reward system does not reward trans- and interdisciplinary approaches. However, many people (especially from the general public, as well as from industry and politics) love them. I am in the fortunate situation to have tenure, so I can work inter- and transdisciplinarily. However, for beginners in the field, who want to establish a scientific career, it is hard to evenImpossible to work that way. It takes time to listen to the other fields, it takes time to talk to them, and this time is not given to most youngsters since they are generally on very short contracts. I think this is also a reason why my field, biomimetics, has such a hard time flying off. Everybody loves it, learning from nature, systemic approaches, transfer to engineering, but only a few can really practice it - and if, again, only in a small area of the field.
Can be critical for making breakthroughs
the CSSS was one of the best examples of interdisciplinary collaboration I have experienced so far, and certainly the best I had experienced at that time.
essential. This is what I do all the time. I am in Omics research/ bioinformatics
Fun!

It can be very powerful if a common language can be established at the begining or very frustrating if everyone tries to keep on becoming interdisciplinary without making an effort to build common ground
Great

It is awesome.  In the case of my CSSS project, I think it wasn't as fruitful as it could have been otherwise, due to where I was in my research interests at the time, which has since changed, but in general I think interdisciplinary collaboration is great.
Essential. Not always straight-forward, but totally worth the effort
Hard, wonderful, needed
I think it's incredibly useful in my day-to-day. (I forecast the weather using traditional statistical and machine learning techniques that are non-traditional in meteorology.)

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Life Sciences;Mathematics and Statistics

Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: It's effort, but extremely enriching effort, on its own merits.
Interdisciplineary collaboration is good and worthwhile, but it takes a lot of extra time and effort.  Many organizations don't understand and provide appropriate support for the extra work.

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Mathematics and Statistics;Computing
Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: Finding a good mode of communication: sometimes the exact same concept exists in different disciplines and it is called different things.
Collaboration was wonderful during CSSS, but I found it frustratingly difficult to continue due to my non-CSSS research circumstances.
It's very important to engage in interdisciplinary collaborations.
Extremely important, and has sparked some of my best research ideas.

I'm a fan of interdisciplinary collaboration.  The group projects back in 1995 were optional.  People with various random interests came together to work on them, but there was no mandate from the instructors to do anything substantial.  One of the other students did organize an informal seminar series where students presented their research to other students.  I participated in this, it was a lot of fun hearing the wide variety of projects from many different fields.
Very important. I feel that communicating with people outside your discipline can be very enlightening, as it give a different picture of the world.
All my projects are interdisciplinary collaborations, I think it's much needed in the environmnetal sciences field.
It’s a vital part of making connections between different areas of expertise
key for science

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Business and Administration
Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: I loved interdisciplinary collaboration. Unfortunately, my projects were not successful as there was a lack of commitment to it.
Best thing in the world: I still have life-long friendship and collaboration with SFI pals!

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Life Sciences;Physical Sciences;Mathematics and Statistics

Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: It was a great project and probably one of the most interesting paper of my articles.

Even though my CSSS interdisciplinary project didn't bear much fruit, the cross-disciplinary exposure was terrific, and I strive to do work that speaks to multiple disciplines even when my collaborations are largely within my own. I actually think that citing and communicating across boundaries is more important than coauthoring across boundaries. Often interdisciplinary coauthors are much more similar that their labels may imply, whereas cross-discipline-citations may involve dialogue between much more theoretically/methodologically distant scholars.
Very necessary if the right attitude is present. Multidisciplinary is not just about disciplines coming together "because". The scientific question should come first.
It's a great thing
full of new unexpected insights
No future with out interdisciplarity

Love it. Can be frustrating when you don't have the strength to keep asking "what" when collaborators accidentally keep dropping domain-specific terms, so I guess really what matters is that you work with people you can communicate well with in other ways.
Both essential and more honored by lip service than by actual rewards in the academy

Discipline_isced: Education;Arts;Humanities;Journalism;Business and Administration;Life Sciences;Computing;Engineering;Architecture and Urban Planning;Social Services;Environmental Protection
Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: essentially important
i love it, it's the core of my research.
I believe it's extraordinarily useful.  Often our research scope is so narrow that we lose sight of other approaches.
It’s critical but challenging in practice.

It's very important, but pragmatically can be difficult once you are not a student, as it is generally not rewarded the same way. At least in my field, you have to be careful that you are doing enough work that is seen as core computing to be able to achieve promotions, tenure, etc.

Can be difficult at times and may not always give the expected payoffs; but when you find the right project, put the effort in and it works, the payoffs are fantastic and that makes it always worthwhile trying
More of it, please.
the CSSS was pivotal to my career trajectory
For Complexity Science, it is practically essential (at least highly desirable).
It is extremely important for science today and has the potential for leading to major advances in knowledge.

Personally and intellectually crucial (IMHO), but not always a good career move. My work at CSSS, ignited a strong drive to return for a PhD, though it took me 10 years to get into a program afte rbeing in industry. CSSS was deeply inspiring. CSSS did impact my choice of studies.
Vital

I actually think it's super important even if I wasn't particularly successful at advancing my own research interests or making those sorts of relationships. Interdisciplinary offers both fertilizer for new directions and potential corrections for excesses

Interdisciplary collaboration helped me salvaging my thesis after running into some unexpected problems. Having been exposed to ideas from evolutionary population genetics rescued my economics thesis. Without interdisciplinary collaboration, I would not have been able to connect some dots and leave the traditional economic lens behind with which economists typically interpreted their simulation results.
It's awesome! Leveraging diverse expertise and perspectives is a great way to yield research that is both technically/scientifically sound and impactful.
Most helpful: applying new viewpoints and  methods to existing problems. Most challenging: developing shared/consensus vocabulary and conceptual ontology.
Intense when on site. Drops off significantly when no longer together.

I think it is awesome... but difficult... and once people go their seperate ways can be VERY hard to get things finished. We have just submitted the publication now (marked as published, but technically I guess just submitted).

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Mathematics and Statistics;Computing
Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: Excellent! -- great opportunity to learn from other people

in my opinion, interdisciplinary collaborations are a key driving force in scientific innovation. By spanning and connecting disciplines, research quality can be improved. That said, good interdisciplinary research demands time and patience and a good deal of focus.

It's very stimulating and truly brings new results by looking at questions from different angles. However, still the academic system sometimes blocks this approach. Furthermore the currency for our career still remain published papers (or preprints). So more has still to be done in order to have this kind of experiences (such as CSSS) fully welcomed by the 'system', and not perceived as a waste of time, afterall ...

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Mathematics and Statistics

Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: great
Essential.
it's hard
Hihgly desirable but the academic system favours specialization over insterdisciplinary research
hard and risky but rewarding and stimulating
hard and risky but rewarding and stimulating

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Business and Administration;Computing

Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: It's super inspiring and motivating! After csss I started seeking collaborators and colleagues from other disciplines more often at my uni. Also, I love your topic of research, we were inspired to do something along similar lines last year, unfortunatelly that project didn't continue but we had so many so interesting discussions. If you want to talk more about that feel free to get in touch (aleksandra.aloric@gmail.com)
Both my personal experience and my understanding of the literature is that interdisciplinary research is more challenging but produces more holistic results.
Amazing, expansive, fluidity. I'm always thinking about design and complexity.
It's fantastic, awe inspiring and motivational.
Extremely important in progressing research and outreach
It is sometimes difficult to publish but worth the effort.
It is essential
You asked about group projects. I don't recall group projects back in 1990.

I think science in general is too siloed and interactions with those from other fields can be very useful. I also think individuals and same-disciplinary teams can consciously draw on theories from other fields. For instance, Price drawing on game theory (economics) to help understand the evolution of ritualistic fighting in animals.

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Mathematics and Statistics
Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: Inspiring, Interesting, but difficult

More, please! The tricky part is to make interdisciplinary collaboration deep enough to be impactful, rather than interesting or fun for its own sake. That takes so. much. work. because it requires integrating fields together, which is a step beyond simply collaborating.
Great way to open your mind and expand the range of subjects that interest you
It's great! The main drawback is that people can lose sight of or undervalue the fields' content questions and focus more on importing methodologies from other fields.
Still trying to publish work from two groups, but difficult w/ people trying to graduate/get jobs. Have about 1.5 manuscripts written and work has been presented at large conferences.
Necessary for me to be happy
Even if collaborations don't pan out, understanding the perspectives from other fields can give you insights into problems that interest you.

I've avidly pursued it -- I've spent the past 5-6 years at an interdisciplinary research institute. However, as a computer scientist, I've found it a bit of a mixed bag. Many fields want to work with CS people for their skills (yay!), but few fields (with the exception of physics) share CS's goal of developing new methods in the abstract. So, what often happens is that I feel like a mercenary (not contributing in my own field), in exchange for getting to work on other people's cool problems.

Not easy, but rewarding. I have become an interdisciplinary communicator among teams that comprise various skills. This is mentally rewarding but sometimes not academically rewarding, when the specialist teams go off and do their own publications, forgetting or downplaying the foundational importance of the match-making. Nonetheless, without combining disciplines we will not solve many of the biggest challenges!

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Life Sciences;Computing;Environmental Protection
Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: I think it's essential in addressing the challenges we face in the world today, across a wide range of issues.

Very important, but there is a need to facilitate their "becoming" by overcoming epistemological obstacles. This goes along with doing more research precisely in the field of interpersonal group relations.

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Mathematics and Statistics;Agriculture

Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: Even though I didn't end up collaborating with people that I met at SFI, I think the approach of interdisciplinary research that I saw there was instrumental in my pursuit of a diverse research career. Starting at Aerospace Engineering, I have now worked in Fluid Dynamics and in modelling soft matter.

Discipline_isced: Social and Behavioral Science;Business and Administration;Architecture and Urban Planning;Health;System Analyst
Interdisciplinary_Thoughts: Interdisciplinarity is nice, but home institutions do not give credit to it
